page.title: 09ECOLOGY NATURAL HISTORY
page.content: This beautiful area of E.Cornwall is a rich field for study.The hedgerows of mixed trees are ancient,most over 2oo years old,and shelter a multitude of winged and crawling creatures and small mammals.In the hedge bottoms and on road verges are found patches of wild flowers,many rare.Here are snowdrop and vinca,"Gipsy"daffodils and stitchwort,violet,primrose and wild hyacinth in profusion.Cranesbill, ragged robin,foxglove and vetches in season-and orchids to treasure.The spinneys are home to birds.Birds of prey include buzzard,sparrowhawk,barn owls and brown owls.Partridge and pheasant abound.Here,too,are badger, fox and grey squirrel. Springs rise, and in their beginnings of marsh and pool are frogs,toads and newts,damsel. flies and dragonflies and a variety of wet land plants.
